69. Nealces, one of the renowned ancients,
was artfully experienced at Invention,
as he revealed with his brush
when he painted a battle at sea,
in which the Persians were fighting against
the Egyptians on the River Nile.
Yet he was troubled and perplexed for a while
about how to depict the waters of the Nile.
right-middleNote here an example of ingenuity in depicting a River or a place.

70. To him it was impossible
to distinguish the Nile from seawater,
so he painted a Crocodile
which, secretly and in silence, seemed to lie in wait
for an ass, which had come to the water’s edge
and stuck his muzzle in the river,
his head submerged
as if he were drinking from it.

71. He did this so that anyone
would easily acknowledge
that this Battle took place on the river Nile,
for this is the food and the place
which Crocodiles especially like.
Such natural indications,
like Persons and Cities, as well as Rivers,
beautifully enrich our works.

right-middleNote here a fine conceit copied from the life of Timanthes: to make observers believe that Venus, if seen from the front, would be the fairest; just as Agamemnon, with head covered, would be deemed the saddest.

72. Be it Water, Sea, Lake, or Spring,
they have all in earlier times by the Ancients
been dedicated to some pure Divinity,
and the particular depictions
remaining here generally resemble one another,
appearing in human form:
one of these depictions, for example,
is the Nile in white marble stone.

73. Whether created by Greek, Italian
or Egyptian hands, there is no mistaking
its beautiful antiquity,
in the courtyard of the Papal Vatican in Rome,
lying under the blue Sky,
and so artfully is the reclining Nile
depicted–yea, in Essence and action–
that it is marvelous and worthy to behold.
